metadata.case_name: K. S. Srinivasan v. Union of India

facts.text: On May 1, 1946, Shri K. S. Srinivasan appointed as Liaison Officer, All India Radio, on pay of Rs. 350 per month in scale Rs. 350-20-450-25/2-550, on recommendation of Federal Public Service Commission; posts permanent and pensionable but filled temporarily on probation for six months.

Designation Liaison Officer changed to Public Relations Officer; posts of Public Relations Officers, Listener Research Officer and Assistant Station Director upgraded to Rs. 450-25-500-30-800 w.e.f. January 1, 1947.

On May 23, 1952, Director General, All India Radio order No. 21 A/50: Appellant appointed to Public Relations Officers grade in quasi-permanent capacity w.e.f. May 1, 1949, after continuous service >3 years, declaration under rr. 3 & 4 Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949, and concurrence of Union Public Service Commission.
On September 3, 1952, Director-General order: Services not required after October 6, 1952.
Appellant representation September 8, 1952: As quasi-permanent PRO, entitled to alternative post in same grade held by non-permanent/quasi-permanent servant.
September 13, 1952: Appointed to officiate as Assistant Station Director, Madras, in purely temporary capacity until further orders.
September 19, 1952: Representation under consideration; suggested apply for Assistant Station Directors posts advertised by UPSC.
October 4, 1952: Further representation claiming entitlement under Temporary Service Rules to retention in same grade post without re-selection by UPSC; enclosed application to UPSC.
March 26, 1953: Appellant interviewed by UPSC for Assistant Station Directors.
April 18, 1953: Informed UPSC not selected; services cannot continue.
May 1953: Memorandum: Post of PRO kept in abeyance.
May 26, 1953: Show cause why services not terminated w.e.f. July 18, 1953.
June 9, 1953: Memorandum: PRO posts form separate cadre from Assistant Station Directors; no protection in ASD post.
July 3, 1953: Received June 9 memorandum.
July 10, 1953: Representation to Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs: Termination violates Art. 311.
August 17, 1953: Notices of termination withdrawn; show cause cancelled.

December 14, 1953: Order No. 1(113)-SI/52: PRO posts (except External Services) held in abeyance August 1952; PRO same grade as ASD; appointed ASD External Services w.e.f. Sept 22, 1952; carries quasi-permanent status per Home Affairs OM No. 54/136/51-NGS dt. April 24, 1952.

August 31, 1955: Secretary, Ministry of Information and Broadcasting: UPSC objected to ASD appointment as contrary to regulations; relinquish ASD or accept temporary Assistant Information Officer (lower pay Rs. 350-25-500-30-620).

September 7, 1955: Final order: Quasi-permanent in PRO grade w.e.f. May 1, 1949; PRO posts (except one permanent) held in abeyance 1952; irregular transfer to ASD; rejected by UPSC; relinquish ASD immediately; offered temporary Assistant Information Officer in Press Information Bureau, subject to UPSC.
October 11, 1955: Order transferring to officiating Assistant Information Officer, Press Information Bureau, immediate effect; hand over ASD charge.
October 19, 1955: Handed over charge under protest.
November 25, 1955: Writ Petition 209-D/1955 in Punjab High Court for certiorari quashing Sept 7 & Oct 11 orders, reinstatement as ASD; summarily dismissed same day.
March 16, 1956: Application for certificate to appeal to SC dismissed.
April 23, 1956: Special leave granted by SC.
April 22, 1956: Petition under Art. 32 challenging Sept 7 order violating Arts. 14 & 16.
In 1952, all PRO posts except one in External Services Division held in abeyance as economy measure; surviving post assigned to permanent incumbent.
Public Relations Officers form a cadre by themselves, not belonging to cadre of Assistant Station Directors.

legal_issues.text: Whether the impugned orders violate the constitutional guarantee under Art. 311(2), specifically whether appellant had a right to the post of Assistant Station Director such that termination/reduction constitutes punishment.

Whether posts of Public Relations Officer and Assistant Station Director are in the same grade or cadre under Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949, allowing carry-over of quasi-permanent status.
Whether order dated December 14, 1953 constitutes an independent declaration of quasi-permanent status in Assistant Station Director post under rr. 3 & 4.
Whether Arts. 14 & 16 violated in petition under Art. 32.

petitioner_arguments.text: Quasi-permanent status in PRO post carried to ASD post as same grade; entitled to retention in service in post of same grade under proviso to r. 6(1)(ii) Temporary Service Rules; no need for UPSC re-selection.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949 rr. 3,4,6(1)(ii) proviso; Art. 311

petitioner_arguments.text: PRO and ASD posts in same grade (identical pay scale, Class II, Programme side); December 14, 1953 order admits same grade; respondent's admission binding.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Fundamental Rule 9(31)(c); Civil Service Regulations art. 29; A.I.R. Manual

petitioner_arguments.text: UPSC opinion neither decisive nor binding; termination violates Art. 311 as forfeiture of right to post.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India; Art. 311(2)

petitioner_arguments.text: Discrimination under Arts. 14 & 16 as others without quasi-permanent status appointed ASD via UPSC.

respondent_arguments.text: Impugned orders in consonance with Temporary Service Rules; quasi-permanent PRO service terminable under r. 6(1)(ii) due to reduction in PRO posts; ASD post not same grade/cadre, so no proviso protection; temporary ASD appointment.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949 r. 6(1)(ii); Fundamental Rule 9(4)

respondent_arguments.text: December 14, 1953 order issued under misapprehension; PRO and ASD different cadres per 1944 reorganisation, 1950 cadre declaration, A.I.R. Manual para 129.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Govt. letters 1944, 1950; A.I.R. Manual Ch. IV para 129

respondent_arguments.text: No independent declaration under rr. 3&4 for ASD; carries status per Home OM but irregularly as different grade; UPSC not consulted as required by r. 4(b).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Temporary Service Rules r. 4(b); Home OM 54/136/51-NGS dt. 24-4-1952

respondent_arguments.text: No violation of Art. 311 as no right to ASD post; offered alternative employment to mitigate hardship.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India

court_reasoning.text: Art. 311(2) applies if servant has right to post under contract/rules; termination otherwise not punishment. Appellant had no right to ASD post as temporary/officiating without quasi-permanent ripening.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Test: whether servant would have action for wrongful dismissal against private employer.

court_reasoning.text: Quasi-permanent in PRO grade (specified post/grade per r.4(a)); PRO posts reduced/held in abeyance 1952 (certified via memoranda); falls under r.6(1)(ii).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reduction includes holding in abeyance, not limited to abolition.

court_reasoning.text: PRO and ASD not same grade/cadre: different per 1944 reorganisation, 1950 cadre (ASD includes specific posts excluding PRO), A.I.R. Manual para 129, FR 9(31)(c) requires identical scales AND same cadre/class.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Same pay/class insufficient; PRO separate cadre.

court_reasoning.text: December 14, 1953 order not independent declaration under rr.3&4: recites carrying PRO status per Home OM assuming same grade; no specification of ASD as specified post w.e.f. date; contrasts May 1952 order; no UPSC consultation required but not intended as declaration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Gives effect to Home OM for shifting within grade, but grades different.

court_reasoning.text: No estoppel; appellant not misled re status. r.4(b) mandatory for subordinate authority but order not declaration. UPSC (Consultation) Reg.3 note excludes temporary.
No discrimination under Arts.14&16; non-selection unfortunate but no fundamental right breach.

holdings.text: Impugned orders do not violate Art. 311(2) as appellant had no right to ASD post; PRO and ASD different grade/cadre; reduction in PRO posts allows termination under r.6(1)(ii); December 14, 1953 not independent quasi-permanent declaration for ASD.

precedents_cited.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Scope of Art. 311; termination is punishment only if right to post exists.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 320(3)(c) consultation directory, not mandatory conferring individual right.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Police, Bombay v. Gordhandas Bhanji
precedents_cited.relevance: Public orders construed objectively by language, not subsequent explanations (dissent).

precedents_cited.case_name: Biswanath Khemka v. The King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar provision in s.256 Govt. of India Act directory (dissent).

precedents_cited.case_name: Montreal Street Railway Company v. Normandin
precedents_cited.relevance: Statutory formalities directory if mandatory causes inconvenience/injustice (dissent).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.311(2) protection against punishment without hearing if right to post; no violation here; Arts.14&16 no discrimination.

statutes_cited.name: Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Quasi-permanent status defined/specified; terminable on reduction in posts unless same grade/cadre post available; no carry-over to ASD.

statutes_cited.name: Fundamental Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Cadre as sanctioned unit; same time-scale requires identical scales and same cadre/class.

statutes_cited.name: Civil Service Regulations
statutes_cited.relevance: Appointments in same class/grade if constituted/recognised as such by authority.

statutes_cited.name: Union Public Service Commission (Consultation) Regulations
statutes_cited.relevance: No consultation needed for certain internal appointments; temporary excludes quasi-permanent per UPSC view.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave and Art.32 petition dismissed; no violation of Art.311(2),14,16; appellant had no right to ASD post as different cadre from PRO; reduction in PRO posts valid; no costs.
outcome.relief_granted: None; sympathetic consideration invited for appellant.

key_quotes.text: "Shortly put, the principle is that when a servant has a right to a post or to a rank either under the terms of the contract of employment, express or implied, or under the rules governing the conditions of his service, the termination of the service of such a servant or his reduction to a lower post is by itself and prima facie a punishment" (Parshotam Lal Dhingra quoted).
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the post of Assistant Station Director is not in the same grade or cadre as the posts of Public Relations Officers."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Public orders, publicly made, in exercise of a statutory authority cannot be construed in the light of explanations subsequently given by the officer making the order of what he meant".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissent: Objective construction of Dec 14, 1953 order.

key_quotes.text: "in conclusion we wish to say that apart from any consideration of mere legal right, this is a hard case."
key_quotes.speaker: court
